For decades, gas turbine engines have been played an important role over various fields, such as jet engines, rockets, power plants, etc. Among them, gas turbines for power generation is one of the main methods of energy generation nowadays. In terms of energy production, the gas turbine method has several benefits compared to other plants, including convenience of starting engine, large power output per mass, low pollutant emission such as carbon dioxide, nitrous oxides(NOx), etc. Especially for emission, fuels without carbon, for instance, hydrogen and ammonia, is rising as carbon neutrality policies came into effect gradually. [2] To fulfill low-emission system, gas turbine plants with fuel lean-burn can play key roll, which means combustion with excess of air, in addition to efficiency for using fuel. Currently those gas turbine combustors in industrial use adopt premixed flame for the most, which combusts with fuel and oxidizer completely before ignition, because of high effectiveness and low emission compared to diffusion flame, which is fuel and oxidizer separately enter the combustion chamber. Also, there are several types of gas turbine combustors; can type, cannular type, can-anunlar type, and annular type. For can-annular type combustors, which combined type and annular type combustor, are commonly used on industrial fields. There are some advantages of can-annular combustors; easy to maintain as each can be removed easily and wored on independently. [3] On the other hand, there are some risks about fuel lean premixed combustors, including a risk due to premixed flame, which have been resolved to some extent today. The most challenging problem is combustion instability, in presence of lean-burn. Moreover to the combustion instability of the combustor itself, the can-annular type combustors have a additional combustion instability about area called a "cross-talk section" that interacts due to the joining at the end of each combustor as Fig.1 shown. This area is used to equalize the pressure in each can [3]. Although instability of can-annular combustor is notable, relatively little research were conducted about combustion instabililty with respect to combustor-to-combustor interaction. The purpose of this paper is to understand basics of characteristics of combustion instabillity, interaction between combustors that could occur in can-annular combustors as well as, comprehending emissions in gas turbine combustor. In the end, we can be expected to use this literature as a reference at future works. [1] K. Moon , H. Jegal , C. Yoon , K.T. Kim , Cross-talk-interaction-induced combustion instabilities in a can-annular lean-premixed combustor configuration, Com- bust. Flame 220 (2020) 178–188. BOYCE, Advanced industrial gas turbines for power generation, The Boyce Consultancy Group, LLC, USA, 2012

Here is a revised version of your paragraph, with some suggestions for improvements: 

Gas turbine engines have played an important role in various fields for decades, including jet engines, rockets, and power plants. Among them, gas turbines for power generation are one of the main methods of energy generation nowadays. Compared to other power plants, the gas turbine method has several benefits, such as convenience of starting the engine, large power output per mass, and low pollutant emissions, such as carbon dioxide and nitrous oxides (NOx). Especially with the rise of carbon-neutral policies, fuels without carbon, such as hydrogen and ammonia, are becoming increasingly important. In order to meet emission standards, gas turbine plants with lean-burn fuel can play a key role in terms of combustion efficiency and low emissions. Currently, most gas turbine combustors in industrial use adopt premixed flames, which completely combust both the fuel and oxidizer before ignition, due to their high effectiveness and low emissions compared to diffusion flames, which allow fuel and oxidizer to enter the combustion chamber separately. The can-annular type combustors, which combine the can and annular types, are commonly used in industrial fields due to their easy maintenance – each can be removed and worked on independently. However, fuel lean premixed combustors carry some risks such as combustion instability, especially in the presence of lean-burn. In can-annular type combustors, this risk is compounded by the presence of a "cross-talk section" that interacts due to the joining at the end of each combustor. Although relatively little research has been conducted about combustion instability with respect to combustor-to-combustor interaction, this paper aims to understand the basics of combustion instability, interactions between combustors in can-annular combustors, and emissions in gas turbine combustors, and provide a reference for future work [1][2][3].

For decades, gas turbine engines have played an important role across various fields, such as jet engines, rockets, and power plants [1]. Among these applications, gas turbines for power generation is one of the main methods of energy generation currently used. In terms of energy production, the gas turbine method has several benefits compared to other plants, including convenience in starting the engine, large power output per mass, and low pollutant emissions such as carbon dioxide and nitrous oxides (NOx) [2]. Hydrogen and ammonia are rising as fuels without carbon, in line with carbon neutrality policies [2]. 

To achieve a low-emission system, gas turbine plants with fuel lean-burn can play a key role in addition to fuel efficiency. Currently, most gas turbine combustors in industrial use adopt a premixed flame, which combusts completely before ignition, because it is more effective and produces lower emissions compared to the diffusion flame, where fuel and oxidizer separately enter the combustion chamber [2]. There are several types of gas turbine combustors, including can type, cannular type, can-annular type, and annular type. Can-annular type combustors, which combine a can and an annular type combustor, are commonly used in industrial fields [3]. One advantage of can-annular combustors is that they are easy to maintain since each can be removed and worked on independently [3].

However, there are still some risks associated with fuel lean premixed combustors, including combustion instability in the presence of lean burn, and more specifically with can-annular type combustors, additional combustion instability in a specific area called the "cross-talk section" that interacts due to the joining at the end of each combustor, as Figure 1 shows [3]. Although the instability of can-annular combustor is notable, relatively little research has been conducted about combustion instability with respect to combustor-to-combustor interaction. 

The purpose of this paper is to understand the basics of the characteristics of combustion instability, the interaction between combustors, which could occur in can-annular combustors, as well as to comprehend emissions in gas turbine combustors. In the end, this literature can be expected to serve as a reference for future works [1][2][3].

Can-annular fuel lean premixed combustor, generally used for industrial gas turbine areas, offers advantages; low emissions, easy startup and maintenance. However, can-annular lean premixed combustor faces challenges with combustion instability, especially in can-to-can interactions. This paper aims to understand the characteristics of combustion instabilities and interactions in can-annular combustors. Resulting from the feedback loop perturbation of the combustion process and natural acoustic mode, thermoacoustic instability is a major concern. The cross-talk and cross-fire tube in can-annular combustors introduces additional possibilities of thermoacoustic instabilities. Experimental comparisons among different cases reveal differences in instability modes and frequencies based on combustor geometry, fuel composition, and inlet conditions. Theoretical and numerical methods are used to validate, with limitations existing for noncylindrical and interacting combustors. Further research is needed to analyze self-excited combustion instabilities in can-to-can interactions using multislit nozzles and cross-fire tubes, simulating industrial can-annular combustors, and improving understanding of combustion instability control.

Can you evaluate the following Materials and Methods subsection? Is it apparent for what purpose this test was performed? Why or why not? Suggest ways to re-write the passage.

Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST)
Participants sorted cards according to color, shape, or number stimuli depicted on the card. Sorting the cards by color was initially verbally reinforced. After a participant responded correctly for 10 consecutive cards in that color category, the participant continued sorting by form and numbers without verbal stimuli or reinforcement. Subsequently, the ratio of correct responses to errors was computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were analyzed. In the WCST (Berg, 1948), test subjects have to correctly identify, implement, and remember sorting rules.

Yes, overall, it is apparent from the passage that the Wisconsin Card Sorting Test was performed in order to measure participants' abilities to identify, implement, and remember sorting rules. However, the passage could be written more clearly, and some more information could be added to provide greater detail on the study methods.

Here's one possible way to re-write the passage with these changes:

The Wisconsin Card Sorting Test (WCST) was administered to each participant. During the testing, participants were presented with cards featuring stimuli in the form of colors, shapes, or numbers, and were asked to categorize the cards accordingly. Initially, participants were instructed to sort the cards by color, and were verbally reinforced for each correct response. Once the participant had correctly sorted 10 cards in a row by color, the verbal reinforcement was removed, and participants needed to continue sorting by form and numbers without any verbal feedback. The ratio of correct responses to errors was then computed, and the numbers of trials, errors, perseverative responses, and perseverative errors were recorded and analyzed. The purpose of the WCST, as described by Berg (1948), is to assess individuals' cognitive flexibility and ability to modify behavior in response to changing environmental cues.

Sure, let me explain it to you. Relative pronouns 'who' and 'whom' are used to refer to people. However, 'who' is used when it functions as the subject of the sentence, while 'whom' is used when it functions as the object of the sentence. For example, "The girl who sings is my neighbor," where 'who' is the subject of the sentence, and "The girl whom my brother invited to the party will sing," where 'whom' is the object of the phrase 'my brother invited to the party.'

The earthquake lights theory: an analysis of earthquake-related UFO sightings

Country UFO sightings for 7 days prior to earthquake Earthquake magnitude Average weekly UFO sightings Descriptions of UFO

Results:
Our analysis aimed to investigate whether there is a link between the number of UFO sightings prior to an earthquake and the earthquake's occurrence. The data we collected regarding earthquake-related sightings of UFOs from various countries within 300 km of the epicenter, during the seven-day period before the earthquake, helped us in this investigation. We have presented the relevant data in Table 1.
Our analysis of the data reveals the following. First, the average weekly UFO sightings recorded prior to an earthquake was higher than the overall average. Second, the countries that recorded the highest number of UFO sightings were those with the higher earthquake magnitudes. Specifically, 75 clusters of high-speed light and 6 blue-green egg-shaped objects were reported in the USA and Canada, respectively. Third, in Russia, a green ball of light was reported, while in India, a fast-moving disc was observed. Finally, in Australia, white flashes of light were recorded. 
Thus, in support of our hypothesis, it is plausible that the significant increase in the frequency of sightings of UFOs during the seven-day period prior to an earthquake was related to an earthquake's occurrence. Our results support the earthquake lights theory, suggesting that UFO sightings could be used to predict an impending earthquake. Further research is warranted to investigate the underlying causes of the phenomenon.

Causal inference is an emerging field in deep learning, which is used to mitigate dataset bias. Traditional machine learning models are based on correlation rather than causation, which means that they can't distinguish between confounding variables and true effects. Causal inference methods, on the other hand, can help to identify causal relationships between variables and infer how they interact with each other. By using these methods, deep learning models can predict the effect of a given input on the output, which enables the mitigation of dataset bias. Techniques such as counterfactual reasoning and causal consistency are becoming popular in deep learning, and they are expected to have a huge impact on the field in the future.

The methodology section consists of 
1. general introduction & overview
2. detailed information about present study
3. justification of choices made
4. indicate where problems occured

Yes, that's correct! It sounds like you learned the basic structure and purpose of the methodology section in a journal paper. In the introduction/overview of the methodology, you typically provide a brief summary of what the study is about and describe the research question or hypothesis. In the detailed information section, you would describe how you conducted the study, including the sample size, data collection procedures, and any statistical analyses performed. The justification of choices made is an important part of the methodology section because it allows you to explain the reasoning behind your research design and demonstrate that your approach is appropriate for your research question. The final section, indicating where problems occurred, is crucial for transparency because it allows other researchers to understand any potential limitations or biases in the study. Did I miss anything or is there anything you would like to add?
I want to know if there are any tips to improve the methodology section after writing a draft.

Yes, I can provide you with a few tips to improve the methodology section after writing a draft:

1. Be clear and concise: Make sure you clearly explain all the details of your study that are relevant to your research question, but don't include any irrelevant or unnecessary information. Your readers should be able to easily understand what you did and why you did it.

2. Use headings and subheadings: Organizing your methodology section into smaller sections using headings and subheadings can help make it easier to read and understand. It can also help you ensure that you have covered all the necessary elements of the methodology.

3. Check for consistency: Make sure that you are consistent in the language that you use throughout the section. For example, make sure that you are using the same tense throughout the section and that you are consistent in how you refer to the participants or the variables.

4. Have someone else review your section: It can be helpful to have someone else (such as a peer or a colleague) who is knowledgeable in your field review your methodology section. They can provide you with feedback on whether your section is clear and complete or suggest improvements you could make to better communicate your research.

5. Review articles in your field: Look at articles in your field to get an idea of how other researchers write their methodology sections. Pay attention to the structure, language, and level of detail that they use in their methodology sections, and consider applying those same strategies to your own writing.

‘Efficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer Design with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation Considering Power Noise’

Methodology

In this study, we propose an efficient design methodology for high bandwidth memory (HBM) interposer using a generative adversarial network (GAN)-based eye diagram estimation technique. The methodology consists of several steps, including raw data generation, target channel and design parameters set-up, eye diagram simulation set-up, preprocessing of training datasets, determining the number of labels and eye diagram datasets, time series to images transformation methods for input datasets, and building Pix2Pix-based GAN for eye diagram estimation.
The process of raw data generation for GAN model training involves several steps, starting with the design specifications of HBM and the definition of the target channel. The design of the HBM interposer and the set-up of design parameters are then carried out, followed by the electromagnetic (EM) simulation of the HBM interposer, S-parameters, and eye diagram. Data collection is performed for training the GAN model. The target channel and design parameters are set up based on the physical dimension and material properties of the HBM interposer. The design target is defined as a victim of a 5mm strip line with adjacent aggressors, and the target channel is designed by fixing the thickness of all layers as 1 um.
For the eye diagram simulation set-up, the input voltage Vin is set to an amplitude of 0.4V, a data rate of 6.4Gbps, and a rise/fall time of 15.6ps/15.6ps. Equivalent source/load elements are set as TX: 50Ω/0.5pF as an equivalent source resistance and load capacitance, and RX: 0.5pF as an equivalent load capacitance, following JEDEC standard JESD238 (HBM3). To evaluate the Power Supply Induced Jitter (PSIJ) in the proposed HBM interposer design, we designed a Power Delivery Network (PDN) to supply power to the HBM interposer. We applied power noise generated by switching multiple drivers simultaneously to the eye diagram simulation. This allowed us to analyze the effects of power noise on signal integrity in the HBM interposer. We examined various factors, such as noise margin, jitter, and eye opening, to investigate the impact of power noise on the design of the interposer. Through this analysis, we were able to identify potential PSIJ issues and propose solutions to mitigate them, thereby improving the overall performance and reliability of the HBM interposer design.
Preprocessing of training datasets involves EM simulation & Transient simulation using HFSS and ADS to extract raw data (csv file) containing labels like width, space, index, time, and density. MATLAB is then used to process raw data, plot eye diagrams, and save image datasets. Python is used to preprocess images, label datasets, create hierarchical data formats file with datasets (HDF5 file), extract datasets, build a GAN network, and train GAN. The number of labels and eye diagram datasets are determined based on the setting of two labels representing width and space, respectively. The minimum and maximum values of the parameters of each label and the step-size determine the total number of datasets. 
Time series to images transformation methods are employed for input datasets. 1-D time series data with high feature complexity due to sequential data can be transformed to enable data analysis through 2-D convolution. Finally, to build a Pix2Pix-based GAN for eye diagram estimation, a dataset containing input images and their corresponding target images is required. Pix2Pix is a supervised learning algorithm that takes an input image and produces an output image in a different style. It has been successfully applied to various image-to-image translation tasks.
In summary, our proposed methodology enables the design and analysis of the entire eye diagram with power noise without conventional time-consuming processes. It also presents a GAN-based eye diagram estimation methodology for fast and optimal design of HBM interposer.

A modelling approach to traffic management and CO exposure during peak hours

Results:

1  Data obtained in previous studies [1, 2] using a fixed on-site monitor indicated that travel by car resulted in lower CO exposure than travel on foot.  2  According to Figo et al. (1999), the median exposure of car passengers was 11% lower than for those walking [2].  3  In our study, modelled emission rates were obtained using the Traffic Emission Model (TEM), a CO exposure modelling framework developed by Ka [3].  4  Modelled results were compared with actual roadside CO concentrations measured hourly at a fixed monitor.  5  Figure 1 shows the results obtained using TEM.
6  As can be seen, during morning peak-time journeys, the CO concentrations for car passengers were significantly lower than for pedestrians, which is consistent with results obtained in previous studies [2].  7  However, the modelled data were not consistent with these results for afternoon journeys. 
8  Although the mean CO concentrations modelled by TEM for afternoon journeys on foot were in line with those of Figo et al., a striking difference was noted when each of the three peak hours was considered singly (Fig. 2).  9  It can be observed that during the first hour (H1) of the peak period, journeys on foot resulted in a considerably lower level of CO exposure.  10  Although levels for journeys on foot generally exceeded those modelled for car journeys during H2, during the last hour (H3) the levels for journeys on foot were again frequently far lower than for car journeys. 
11  A quantitative analysis to determine modelling uncertainties was applied, based on the maximum deviation of the measured and calculated levels within the considered period.  12  Using this approach, the average uncertainty of the model prediction for this study slightly exceeds the 50% acceptability limit defined by Jiang [7].  13  Nevertheless, these results suggest that data obtained using TEM to simulate CO exposures may provide more sensitive information for assessing the impact of traffic management strategies than traditional on-site measurement.

‘Efficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer Design with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation Considering Power Noise’

Results
The study aims to design an efficient High Bandwidth Memory (HBM) Interposer with Generative Adversarial Network (GAN)-Based Eye Diagram Estimation, considering power noise. The principles of GAN training were analyzed through the objective function, and the analysis of the training progress of GAN was conducted through discriminator and generator error.

Regarding the principles of GAN training, it was found that binary cross-entropy can be applied to the discriminator in GANs, as the discriminator in GANs is a binary classification problem representing true as 1.0 and false as 0.0. It was also observed that cross-entropy can be greater than 1.0 with logarithmic calculations, providing much greater feedback on the wrong answer. The ideal Binary Cross-Entropy (BCE) loss is 0.693 in situations where the discriminator and generator are balanced.

In the analysis of training progress of GAN, it was noted that according to the mathematical definition of binary cross-entropy, the ideal value of the loss function is ln 2. If the error of the discriminator is less than the ideal value, the discriminator outpaces the generator, and if it is similar to the ideal value, the generator is being trained well. It was found that the error in the discriminator is oscillated in between, indicating that the discriminator and generator compete with each other and learn well.
 
	Figure 1 Error in discriminator according to epoch shows the process of convergence
 


Figure 2 Error in generator according to epoch ensures that the generator is trained well

As the epoch increases, the generator converges appropriately to produce various and plausible data. It is shown that if the epoch is excessively increased, the learning quality may deteriorate. The results of this study provide valuable insights into the training progress of GAN and eye diagram estimation. These findings can be useful in the design of efficient HBM interposer with GAN-based eye diagram estimation, considering power noise.

I learned about comma rules. After a conjunctive adverb like then is placed at the beginning, we should use commas. Isn't right?

Close! When a conjunctive adverb like "then" is used as a transitional word to connect two independent clauses in a sentence, then it is usually preceded by a semicolon and followed by a comma. For example: "I spent all day studying; then, I went to bed early." Does that make sense?
Then, when we should use semicolon? Please take some examples.

Good question! A semicolon is used to connect two independent clauses in a sentence, without using a coordinating conjunction like "and," "but," or "or." Here are some examples:

- "I have a big test tomorrow; I need to study all night."
- "She went on vacation to Hawaii; he went to Florida."

Note that you can also use a semicolon in place of a period to separate two closely related sentences. For example: "I love to read; it's my favorite hobby."

I learned about the hyphen rules. But I was not fully understood about it. Why should I hyphenate the following: Low-frequency ? Just writing 'low frequency' without hyphen is wrong?

Yes. When you use a hyphen between two words like "low-frequency," it creates a compound modifier. This means that the two words now function together as one unit to describe or modify the noun that comes after them. In the case of "low-frequency," it is describing a noun, so it needs to be hyphenated. If you simply wrote "low frequency" without a hyphen, it would not convey the same meaning as "low-frequency." Without the hyphen, "low" and "frequency" would be read as separate words, and the reader would not understand that they were meant to be taken together as a unit modifying the noun. Does that make sense?
Then you mean "low-frequency" plays a role of an adjective modifying following noun? whereas "low frequency" is just  a noun itself. Right?

Yes, exactly. "Low-frequency" serves as a compound adjective, which describes or modifies the noun that follows it. On the other hand, if you write "low frequency" without the hyphen, it would be read as two separate words, and each word would stand alone as a noun.
Then how about "long-ranged interaction"? In class, it was a wrong phrase. Can you explain why this is wrong?

Yes, "long-ranged interaction" is not correct because it violates the rules of hyphenation for compound modifiers. The correct form should be "long-range interaction" that is hyphenated since "long-range" acts as a single descriptive unit that modifies "interaction" as a compound modifier. 

The problem with "long-ranged" is that it contains an adjective, "long," and a verb, "ranged." This creates confusion and makes it difficult for readers to understand the intended meaning. So, we should use the correct form of "long-range interaction" to convey clear meaning.

I want to know about the discussion part in the paper obviously. In the class, there is an comparison between introduction and discussion. But I wonder the difference between discussion and results part.

Great question! In the discussion section of a scientific paper, you are interpreting your results and placing them in a larger context. This section is where you can take a step back and think about what your findings mean. You can identify patterns or trends and explain them, or hypothesize about further research that might be needed. In contrast, the results section is where you present your findings in a straightforward manner, often through tables, graphs or figures. You don't interpret or analyze your results in this section; you simply present them. Overall, the distinction between the two sections is that the results section presents the raw data, while the discussion section places the results in a broader context and offers interpretations of what they might mean. Does that help answer your question?
Then usually people write their discussion in the results part in the scientific paper?

No, it is not appropriate to write a discussion in the results part of a scientific paper. As I mentioned earlier, the results section simply presents the raw data that you have collected, often in the form of tables, graphs, or figures. This section does not offer any interpretation or analysis of the data that you have collected. In contrast, the discussion section is where you can interpret and analyze the results, and discuss their implications. It is important that you keep these two sections separate in your paper.
Then what is the difference between discussion part and conclusion? Because I usually read the paper in order of results following conclusion, not discussion part.

That's a great question. The conclusion is the section of the paper that follows the discussion and sums up the main findings of the study in a concise manner. It should be brief and focused solely on summarizing the key findings of the study, without presenting any new information or interpretation. In contrast, the discussion offers a more detailed analysis and interpretation of the results, and often presents possible explanations for those results. The discussion section is where you can speculate about potential mechanisms underlying your observations or propose future research directions. The conclusion, therefore, offers a brief summary of the study's main findings, while the discussion offers a more in-depth analysis and interpretation of the results, including their broader significance or potential implications. Does that help clarify the difference between the discussion and the conclusion?

Well done! Overall, your results section provides a clear and concise summary of your study findings. However, there are a few suggestions that may help improve the clarity of your writing. Firstly, in the first sentence, consider rephrasing the sentence to "Our study investigated the relationship between personality types and the presence or absence of siblings among students in the F class of Scientific Writing."

Secondly, in the third sentence, it would be helpful to provide the actual number of students in the survey, for example "Out of the total number of students surveyed, 86.7% were only child while 13.3% had siblings."

However, there was a higher percentage of extroverted students among the having-siblings group."

Overall, great work! Keep practicing and refining your scientific writing skills.
Thanks. Finally, can i get some tips about writing results section? Like common phrase.

Yes, of course! Here are some common phrases you can use to write your results section:

- "The data shows that..." 
- "As shown in Figure X, the results demonstrate..." 
- "A higher/lower percentage was observed in group X compared to group Y." 
- "The results suggest that..." 
- "The statistical analysis indicates that there is a significant difference between X and Y." 
- "The findings support the hypothesis that..." 
- "There was no significant difference between X and Y." 
- "The results provide insight into..." 
- "The trends indicate..." 

Remember to keep the language concise and clear, and to always refer back to your research question or hypothesis. Additionally, it's important to provide clear and accurate visual aids such as tables, graphs, or diagrams where necessary.

The recommended number of words for the conclusion section of a scientific paper can vary depending on the specific journal or publication you are submitting to. However, as a general guideline, the conclusion section should be concise and to the point, typically consisting of 5-10% of the total word count of the paper. 

In other words, if your paper is 5000 words long, your conclusion section should be around 250-500 words. It's important to remember that the conclusion section should not introduce any new information, but rather summarize the key findings of the study and their implications. 

Ultimately, the length of the conclusion section will depend on the specific requirements of the journal or publication you are submitting to, so it's always a good idea to check their guidelines for specific word count recommendations.

Today I learned about the comma rules. When there is a list that contains two or more elements, we should use commas to separate them.
Great! It sounds like you learned about the use of commas in lists during our class today. Did you have any questions about the specific comma rules we discussed?
can you explain about comma rules in more details

Certainly! Commas are often used in scientific writing to separate items on a list, as you mentioned. Here are a few other situations where we commonly use commas:

1. Commas are used to separate coordinate adjectives (adjectives that modify a noun independently of each other). For example: "The bright, sunny day was perfect for a picnic."

2. Commas are used to separate independent clauses when they are joined by a coordinating conjunction (for, and, nor, but, or, yet, so). For example: "I love spending time outdoors, but I also enjoy reading inside."

3. Commas are used to enclose introductory elements such as phrases, clauses, or adverbial phrases at the beginning of a sentence. For example: "While I was running, I saw a deer in the woods."

4. Commas are used to set off nonessential elements within a sentence. For example: "The book, which was written by a famous author, became a bestseller."

These are just a few examples of situations where we use commas in scientific writing. It's important to use commas correctly to avoid confusion or ambiguity. Let me know if you have any other questions!

Additionally, selecting the appropriate visuals to illustrate the results can sometimes be more effective at communicating the findings to the reader than written text alone. It is also important to discuss the key results in detail, and to make sure that you comment on their significance and how they relate back to your research question, hypothesis, and methodology.

Today I learned about the colon and semicolon. 
A colon introduces a formal list, long quotation, equation, or definition.
Semi-Colon: a semi-colon either joins two independent clauses (closely linked in thought) or separates complex items in a list.

Yes, that's correct! You learned about the uses of the colon and semicolon in academic writing. A colon is used to introduce a formal list, which can be a list of items, a quotation, an equation, or a definition. On the other hand, a semicolon is used to connect two independent clauses that are closely linked in thought, or to separate complex items in a list where commas may cause confusion. Great job on summarizing what you learned today!

Review Writing Tips for Methods
- Most of this section will be written in the past tense.
  → If you are describing something that you did, use the past tense.
  → If you need to describe currently accepted practices, use the present tense.

- Write any procedure in chronological order.
  → Try to give the old information first and the new information second.
- The passive voice is usually used to avoid I / We; However, active voice is not forbidden. Try to make passive structures using short passive forms. (short and concise!)

※ Trend for using voice 
- Many fields (especially Engineering) : tend to abstain from using the first person pronounced like I or We. 
- Natural science (especially Biology or Chemistry journal) : active voice becomes quite a lot more popular and common
- High impact journal (Nature, Science…) : a lot of instances for I or We

  → Recommendation :  Look at the journal and question, and see what is common in terms of language usage, (active or passive) then decide for yourself which one you think would be appropriate for the journal you will submit to. = Case by Case!

Yes, I see. It sounds like you learned about the importance of using the correct tense when writing about methods, and how to structure procedures in a clear and logical order. You also learned about the use of passive and active voice, and how this can differ depending on the field and the type of journal you are writing for. It's important to be aware of these trends and decide which approach is most appropriate for the particular journal you are submitting to.

4.	DEEP LEARNING

Deep Ensemble Convolutional Neural Network Learning
Convolutional Neural Network (CNN) is a method of deep learning that has been used in many industries for object detection and classification since it was developed by LeCun et al[10]. CNNs use multiple arrays to store weights in a feature map and extract information. Since the data is collected through pulse-echo mode, the attenuation of the signal is not obvious, which requires the advanced feature extraction ability of the Convolutional Neural Network (CNN). In CNN training, even for the same data, 1-D CNN recognizes and extracts time series information, and 2-D CNN extracts spatial information caused by nonlinearity as different information. To utilize these features, we devised a deep ensemble CNN (DECNN). This network is composed of two architectures: a 1-D CNN that uses 1-D laser ultrasound signals as input, and a 2-D CNN that rearranges the 1-D signals into 2-D to extract features. The values from each architecture are then flattened into a single layer and classified through a softmax layer. For each architecture of 1-D CNN and 2-D CNN, batch normalization is used to improve the performance of the gradient after convolution, and the Rectified Linear Unit (ReLU) layer is used as an activation function to prevent gradient vanishing[11,12]. The detailed architecture and hyperparameters of the CNN are listed in Figure 4, Table 2. The developed DECNN was trained using Matlab R2023b with CPU Intel i7-12700K and GPU NVIDIA GeForce RTX 4090Ti.  The performance evaluation of the network evaluates the multi-classification model based on True positive, True negative, False positive, and False negative present in the confusion matrix of the test set. To evaluate the multi-classification model, accuracy, mean average precision, and recall are used as performance metrics, and these values are calculated. All performance metrics were calculated with k-fold cross-validation to verify the bias of the data. The formulas precision and recall are given in Eqn. 1. and Eqn. 2., respectively.

Today I learned about the numbering rules. It is needed to choose appropriate type between numbers and numerals.

Yes, that's correct. In scientific writing, it's important to use the proper numbered or non-numbered format when presenting information. Numeric systems are used for counting, identifying, and ordering whereas numeral systems are used to represent numbers in a written form. Can you give me an example of when you might use numbers versus numerals in your writing?
It is derived from 530 researchers that there were fifty-two 12 inch snails in the territory.

Actually, in scientific writing, numbers one through nine are typically spelled out with letters, while numbers 10 and above are generally presented as numerals. So, a more appropriate way to write your sentence might be:

"It is derived from 530 researchers that there were 52 12-inch snails in the territory."

Additionally, it's important to note that units of measurement, such as inches in your example, should always be abbreviated and written in lowercase letters. So, an even better way to write this sentence would be:

"It is derived from 530 researchers that there were 52 12-inch snails in the territory." 

Does that make sense?
No. If there are two numbers next to each other, it is better to write one out and use numerals for the other.

Yes, that's correct. This is also known as the "mixed numbers" format, and it can help to improve the readability of your writing. So, a better way to write your original sentence would be:

"It is derived from 530 researchers that there were 52 twelve-inch snails in the territory."

In this case, "12" is written as a numeral, while "fifty-two" is spelled out in letters. Also note that "twelve-inch" is hyphenated to indicate that it is a compound word, and that "inch" is written in lowercase letters.

Why is the Results section important in the scientific writing?

Yes, that's a great question. The Results section is one of the most important parts of a scientific paper because it presents the findings of the study. This section should be written in a clear and concise manner, using tables, graphs, and figures to help illustrate the data. Today, I learned about introduction part of the thesis. Introduction can be divided into five stages. First Stage: General statements about a field of research to provide the reader with a setting for the problem to be reported.
Second Stage: More specific statements about the aspects of the problem already studied by other researchers.
Third Stage: Statement(s) that indicate the need for more investigation.
Fourth Stage: Very specific statement(s) giving the purpose/objectives of the writer’s study.
Fifth Stage: Optional statement(s) that give a value or justification for carrying out the study.

Yes, that's right! In scientific writing, the introduction section is an essential part of the thesis and takes the reader from a broad and general statement of the research problem to the specific objectives of the study. The introduction section can be divided into five stages as you mentioned - a general statement about the research field, specific statements about past research, indicating the need for further research, giving the purpose and the objectives of the study, and providing value or justifications for carrying out the study. These five stages ensure that the reader is oriented to the subject matter and interested in the research question. Well summarized!

Also, I learned that there are many rules when using commas, semicolons or colons. For example, 1. to avoid confusion, use commas to separate words and word groups with a series of three or more. 2. use a comma when an -ly adjective is used with other adjectives.  3. Use a comma to separate two strong clauses joined by a coordinating conjunction --and, or, but, for, nor. You can omit the comma if the clauses are both short. 4. use a semicolon in place of a period to separate two sentences where the conjunction has been left out. 5. Use the colon after a complete sentence to introduce a list of items when introductory words such as namely, for example, or that is do not appear.

Yes, you've got the right idea. Punctuation plays a massive role in effective scientific writing, and it involves using it correctly to enhance clarity, coherence, and simplicity of the text. When dealing with commas, rules such as separating items in a list, decluttering long sentences, or avoiding confusion when word groups stand next to each other come in handy. Using a semicolon is crucial when separating two related sentences without using any conjunctions. Finally, the colon is also used in scientific writing to separate main notions or ideas, especially when introducing a list.

Today I learned about writing method material for scientific research paper. Explanations about materials can be divided into conventional material and specifically designed material.

Yes, that's correct. In scientific writing, it's important to provide a detailed description of the materials used in your research. As you mentioned, these descriptions can be divided into two categories: conventional materials and specifically designed materials. Conventional materials are those that are already well-known and readily available, such as chemicals, laboratory equipment, or biological specimens. Specifically designed materials, on the other hand, may have been created specifically for the purposes of your research, and require a more detailed explanation. This could include things like custom-designed software or complex experimental setups. By providing a clear and concise description of the materials used in your research, you can help ensure that your results are reproducible and contribute to the advancement of scientific knowledge.
For explaining conventional material, present tense is commonly used.

Yes, that's correct. When explaining conventional materials, it is common to use the present tense, as these materials are already well-known and in use by other researchers. For example, if you were describing a chemical that you used in your experiment, you might write something like, "Sodium chloride is added to the solution in order to...", rather than "Sodium chloride was added to the solution in order to...". This helps to emphasize the fact that this material is widely known and accepted in the scientific community, and that you are building upon existing knowledge. However, it's important to follow the specific guidelines and style requirements of the journal or publication you are submitting to, as they may have their own conventions for describing materials.
In method material, there is a part called principles.

Yes, that's correct. In scientific writing, the "Principles" section is an important part of the methodology or materials and methods section of a research paper. This section contains information about the scientific principles or theories that underlie the methods or techniques used in the research. The principles section provides a theoretical framework or justification for the procedures and methods described in the paper. Here, you can explain the scientific basis for why you've chosen a particular method or approach, giving your reader more context and understanding of your research. By including a clear and detailed description of the scientific principles underlying your research, you can help to ensure that others can reproduce your experiments or build upon your findings in the future.
Principles have to be written in logical order

Yes, that's correct. When writing the principles section of the methodology or materials and methods section of a research paper, it's important to present the information in a logical and organized sequence. This means that you'll want to start with the most foundational principles and theories that relate to your research, and then move on to the more specific or specialized methods that you used in your own study. By presenting your principles in a logical order, you can help readers understand the progression of your research and the reasoning behind your methods. It's also a good idea to consult the specific author guidelines for the journal you're submitting to, as they may have certain expectations or requirements for how the principles section should be structured or presented.
Today I learned about how to write result. We usually use passive tenses when writing results.

Yes, that's correct. In scientific writing, it's common to use passive voice in the results section because it focuses more on the experiment and the data rather than the person who conducted it. Was there anything else that stood out to you in the discussion about writing the results section?
When should we use present tense and past tense when explaining results?

Great question! You should use the present tense to describe your results when discussing facts or concepts that are generally true or when describing your experimental design. You should use the past tense when you are describing the specific results of your experiment. It's important to be consistent with the tense you use throughout your results section. When in doubt, it's a good practice to use past tense to describe the results of the experiment.
The results section should contain frequency, causality,... what else?

Good question! The results section of a scientific paper should contain several elements, including:
- Descriptive statistics, such as sample size, means, and standard deviations.
- Inferential statistics, such as p-values, t-values, and confidence intervals, that show the significance of the findings.
- Graphs, tables, or figures to help visually display the data and assist readers in interpreting the results.
- Explanations of any unexpected findings or results that don't support the hypothesis.
- Interpretations of the data, tying the findings back to the experimental question being asked.

Remember, the goal of the results section is to present the data objectively and clearly, without interpretation or speculation on the meaning of the results.
We can soften the causal statement in results.

Yes, that's right. In scientific writing, it's important to present causation carefully and accurately. In the results section, it's common to use language that is cautious and tentative when describing causation. This may include using words like "suggest," "indicate," or "imply" instead of stating causation directly. This approach acknowledges that there may be factors outside the experiment that could also be influencing the results. Additionally, being cautious in your language helps to avoid making overreaching claims about the findings.
Result and Discussion paragraph usually uses soften statements.

Yes, that's correct. In scientific writing, it's important for the author to remain neutral and objective in their language and statements. This is especially important in the Results and Discussion section, where the author is presenting and interpreting data. Using softened or hedged language can help to accurately represent the data without overstating findings or making unwarranted claims. Can you give me an example of a soften statement you learned to use in your class?

Great job! Your example is a good use of a softened statement. Instead of making a definitive statement that smoking causes lung cancer in people over 50, you are presenting the data as indicating a potential link between the two. This is a more tentative statement that acknowledges that there may be other factors at play, but still allows the reader to draw their own conclusions from the data presented. Keep up the good work! How does different modals give different meanings in softening statement?

That's an excellent question! In scientific writing, we use modals to express the probability, likelihood, and certainty of a claim. For example, "may," "could," "might," and "can" are modals that indicate that something is possible or likely, but not certain. On the other hand, "should," "must," and "will" are modals that indicate a high level of certainty. The use of different modals in softening statements can convey different levels of certainty or uncertainty about a finding or claim and signal to the reader the strength of the evidence supporting the claim. For example, if you say "The data suggest that smoking may increase the risk of lung cancer," the word "may" indicates that the data is not conclusive and that other factors could be contributing to the observed effect. However, if you say "The data show that smoking will always lead to lung cancer," the use of "will" implies a high degree of certainty and could overstate the findings.

What is the difference in meaning between healthy and healthful?

Although "healthy" and "healthful" are often used interchangeably, there can be a slight difference in meaning between the two words. 

"Healthy" usually means that something is already in a good health condition or that it promotes good health.

For instance, "I feel healthy today." or "Eating fruits and vegetables is a healthy choice."

On the other hand, "healthful" refers to something that has properties or characteristics that promote good health. It's usually used to describe things that are good for you, such as a healthy diet, or a healthful lifestyle.

For example, "A healthful diet includes whole grains, lean protein, fruits, and vegetables." or "A healthful lifestyle consists of regular exercise, a balanced diet, and sufficient sleep." 

So while the difference is subtle, it basically comes down to whether we are referring to something that is healthy or something that promotes health.

What does it mean by non-restrictive sentence?

A non-restrictive clause/sentence is a clause which can be omitted without affecting the essential meaning of the sentence. It is sometimes called a non-essential clause because it does not restrict or limit the meaning of the noun it describes. As a result, it takes a comma before and after the clause. In other words, a non-restrictive clause adds additional information to a sentence that is not necessary for understanding the sentence. For example, in the sentence "My sister, who is a doctor, lives in New York", the information "who is a doctor" is non-essential to the meaning of the sentence because the noun "my sister" is already identified. Therefore, the phrase is set off by a comma to indicate that it provides additional, non-essential information.

Should I use that or which here?
That is a book that I have not yet read.
In this sentence, you should use "that" because the relative clause "that I have not yet read" is restrictive information that limits the meaning of the sentence. The sentence is correct as written.
Can you provide me with the general structure of how a methodology section must be written?

Yes, sure. The methodology section typically begins with an introduction that explains the overall approach to the research and the methods that will be used. This is followed by a detailed description of the specific methods that were employed in the study, including any relevant equipment, materials, or instruments that were used. The section should be written in the past tense and should be detailed enough so that someone else could replicate the study. Finally, it should also include a discussion of any limitations or potential sources of error in the methods used. Does that help answer your question?
Please provide them in bullet list

Sure, here's a bullet-point list of the general structure of a methodology section:

- Introduction that explains the overall approach to the research and the methods that will be used
- Detailed description of specific methods used in the study
- Description of any relevant equipment, materials, or instruments used
- Section should be written in past tense
- Section should be detailed enough so someone else could replicate the study
- Discussion of any limitations or potential sources of error in the methods used

So there is no need to mention or compare our methodology with previous research in this particular section?

Therefore, you generally wouldn't include a comparison with previous research in this section. Instead, you could mention any previous studies you used as a basis for developing your methodology in the introduction or discussion sections.

However, if you are using a modified version of a method that has been previously used, it would be appropriate to mention this modification and the reason behind it in your methodology section.
okay, understood. Now, can you provide me with a bullet list of introduction structure?

- Begin with a brief statement of the research topic and its importance or significance.
- Provide relevant background information to give context to the study.
- State your research question or hypothesis.
- Outline the study's main objectives or aims.
- Give an overview of the organization of the paper. 
- State the main contributions of the study.

How long is it normally written?

The length of the introduction section can vary depending on the specific requirements or preferences of the publication or professor, but in general, it should be between one to three paragraphs. In terms of word count, it could be roughly around 150-500 words. The most important aspect of the introduction is to clearly and concisely convey the relevance and significance of the study to the reader.
In introduction, we must be able to fully catch the reader attention. Do you have a way to achieve this? Like relating our research WHY with current issue or advancement?

Yes, that's correct. One effective strategy for catching the reader's attention is to highlight the relevancy of the research to current issues or advancements. This can be done by briefly discussing how your research topic ties into larger societal issues or by highlighting a current situation that your research addresses. Another way to grab the reader's attention is by posing a thought-provoking question or presenting a statement that challenges the reader's assumptions or beliefs. 

Overall, the goal of the introduction is to clearly and succinctly explain the relevance of the study to the reader and motivate them to continue reading.
I bet there shouldn't be a lot of citation appear in the introduction, should it?

You're correct! In general, there shouldn't be a lot of citations in the introduction section. Citations are typically reserved for the literature review or discussion sections where you are discussing previous research or findings. Instead, the introduction should focus on providing background information and setting the stage for your research question or hypothesis. However, if there are any particularly important or relevant studies that you want to highlight in the introduction, it's acceptable to include a few brief citations. In general, it's best to keep citations to a minimum in the introduction so that it remains clear and concise.

On the other hand, as object detection and segmentation have evolved, researchers have focused on the pose information of individual pig in an image [ 7 ]. CV technology provides a variety of tools to efficiently manage the health and welfare of pig.

Yes, your opening paragraph is interesting and provides a good overview of the topic you are discussing. You have introduced the concept of Smart Livestock Farming (SLF), its benefits and its use of computer vision (CV) technology to monitor the health and welfare of pigs. You have also briefly mentioned the different types of CV technology used in the livestock industry, such as image processing, image classification, object detection, and segmentation, which shows that you are well-versed in the subject matter. Overall, your opening paragraph is engaging and effectively sets the stage for the rest of your paper.
how can I improve that paragraph?

One way to improve your opening paragraph is to make it more concise. While you provide a good overview of the topic, it can be a bit wordy and difficult to follow at times. Here's one possible way to revise the paragraph:

"Smart Livestock Farming (SLF) is a new concept in the livestock industry that uses computer vision (CV) technology to monitor the health and welfare of animals. By automatically tracking parameters like behavior, activity, and pose information, SLF reduces the need for human intervention, which can be cost-effective and less stressful for the animals. CV technology offers a range of tools for monitoring pigs, including image processing, image classification, object detection, and segmentation. Researchers have used these tools to classify pig behaviors, detect abnormal behavior or disease, estimate body composition traits and body weights for regression, and obtain pose information for individual pigs in an image. Overall, CV technology has the potential to greatly enhance the management of pig health and welfare in SLF systems."

This revision cuts out some of the unnecessary detail from the original paragraph while still conveying all the key information. It also clarifies the relationship between SLF and CV technology and presents the information in a more organized and easy-to-follow way.
In the original paragraph I mentioned about low-level CV and high-level CV. Do I need to briefly elaborate about the definition of both? Or is it already a standard term in computer vision field?

It would be a good idea to briefly explain what is meant by the terms 'low-level CV' and 'high-level CV' for readers who may not be familiar with this specific jargon. By providing quick definitions or context on how they are used in your article you can help make your work more accessible to a wider audience. However, it is not necessary to provide an extensive explanation on this topic as they are relatively standard terms within the computer vision field and most readers who are familiar with this topic would already be aware of their meaning.
can you provide an example on how I should briefly explain them?

Of course! Here's an example of how you could explain the difference between low-level CV and high-level CV in a brief and concise way:

"Low-level CV refers to the use of image processing methods to extract information about an image, such as its color or texture. High-level CV, on the other hand, involves the use of advanced algorithms to interpret an image and extract high-level semantic information, such as the detection or classification of objects within an image. While low-level CV is useful for tasks like image enhancement or restoration, high-level CV is often used for more complex applications, such as object detection or scene understanding." 

With a brief explanation like this, readers who may not be familiar with these terms can easily understand the difference between low-level CV and high-level CV, without getting bogged down in technical jargon.
is pig a standard term that is appropriate to use here? or is there any other term?

Yes, "pig" is a common term used in the scientific literature when referring to domesticated swine. It is an appropriate term to use in this context, particularly since you are discussing research in the livestock industry. However, if you feel that another term would be more appropriate, you could consider using "porcine" as an alternative.
what are the red flags you can find in the paragraph I provided previously? Please give me list of those

Yes, that's correct - starting your introduction with a hook is a great way to grab your reader's attention and draw them in to your paper. In the precision livestock domain, an example of a hook related to pig activity might be:

"Did you know that a single pig can generate up to 2.4 pounds of manure per day? With the global population projected to reach 9 billion by 2050, finding sustainable ways to manage this waste is becoming more important than ever. Does that make sense to you?
Is it okay to use interogative sentence as an opening?

Yes, using an interrogative sentence as your opening can be an effective way to engage your reader and create curiosity. It can encourage your reader to think about a question and prompt them to read further to find out the answer. However, be careful not to use too many questions in your introduction or it could come across as a quiz or a list of trivia. Also, the question you ask should be relevant and related to the topic of your paper.
Okay, so I am pondering about citation. Do we need to cite everyting that we write in the paper? Can you give me guidelines about what needs to be cited and what are okay to not be cited?

Great question! You do not need to cite everything you write in your paper, but you do need to give credit to any sources that you rely on for ideas, information, or opinions. Here are some general guidelines for when to cite a source:

1. When you directly quote someone else's words or use an image, chart, or graph that was created by someone else, you must cite the source.

2. When you summarize or paraphrase someone else's idea or argument, you must still cite the source. Even though you've put the idea or argument in your own words, it's still not your original thought.

3. When you use information that is not common knowledge, you must cite the source. For example, if you're writing about a historical event or a scientific study that is not widely known, you should provide a reference for your readers.

4. When you use someone else's data, statistics, or research results, you must cite the source.

It's better to err on the side of caution and cite more than you think you need to. Failing to give credit to sources can result in accusations of plagiarism, which is a serious academic offense.

So, I have chosen a particular measurement for my experiment. Let's say, I choose to aggregate the data into one hour each, instead of 5 minutes or any other time quantifiers. To make this assumption stronger, do I need to seek for references and cite, or I just need to prove it based on my data?

If you are making a decision to aggregate the data into one hour each and this is not a common or standard practice in your field, then it would be best to seek for references to support your decision. Citing references to support your decision will strengthen the validity and reliability of your experiment. This indicates that you have made an informed decision based on previous research and expert opinions. Additionally, citing a reference or two also shows that your research is grounded and related to the field of study. However, if aggregating the data into one hour each is already commonly used in your field, then it may not be necessary to cite references in support of this decision.

I learned about parallelism. It means that you are listing or comparing and contrasting items or ideas. Parallelism means that each item in a list or in a comparison follows the same grammatical pattern.

Great! Let's review your essay together and see how we can apply parallelism to make it clearer and more cohesive. 

Can you give me a brief overview of your essay and tell me what your main argument or point is? We'll start by making sure your thesis statement is strong and clearly stated.

My essay is about the reason why government should help those most in need, not all of its citizens. There are two reasons for my opinion. First, when government helps all of its citizens,  ore people who are in need will be neglected. Second, people who are very wealthy don't need any help from the government.

Great, let's start revising your essay with parallelism! 

First, let's look at your thesis statement. It is clear, but we can make it more parallel to emphasize your main points. One way to do this is to use a "not only, but also" structure. You can say "Not only should the government help those most in need, but it should also avoid providing aid to those who are wealthy." This structure helps to show the contrast between the two sides of your argument, and also creates a parallel sentence structure. 

Next, let's look at your body paragraphs. You mentioned two reasons for your opinion, so we can make those more parallel as well. For example:

- First, by focusing aid on those most in need, the government can ensure that resources are not wasted on those who do not require it. This targeted approach can provide greater support for those struggling to make ends meet.
- Second, providing aid to the wealthy creates a disparity in the distribution of resources. The government has a responsibility to prioritize the needs of its most vulnerable citizens, rather than providing unnecessary aid to those who already have the means to support themselves.  

In both of these statements, we used similar sentence structures and parallel phrasing to make the argument clearer and more cohesive. 

Now let's move on to your conclusion. You can use parallel structure here as well to summarize your main points. For example:

- In conclusion, the government should focus its aid on those who are most in need, rather than attempting to provide assistance to all citizens. By doing so, we can ensure that resources are distributed more fairly, and that those who require the most support receive it. 

Here, we used similar phrasing to the thesis statement at the beginning of the essay, which creates a sense of closure and reinforces your argument. 

Remember to keep your ideas clear, concise, and parallel throughout the essay. I hope this helps, and let me know if you have any further questions!

I learned about process writing. to write a process essay, there should be an introductory paragraph, body, and concluding paragraph. Also, you should use chronological order signal words and phrases such as 'first, then, meanwhile, gradually, finally' and subordinators such as 'after, since, as, until'.

Great! Based on what you have learned about process writing, let's take a look at your essay and see how we can help revise it.

First, let's focus on the introduction. Make sure that it sets the stage for the process you will be discussing. It should be clear to the reader what the process is and what you are trying to accomplish.

Next, let's move on to the body of the essay. It's important to use chronological order signal words and phrases, such as 'first, then, meanwhile, gradually, finally' and subordinators such as 'after, since, as, until'. This will help you ensure that the process is clear and easy to follow.

Pay attention to the transition between paragraphs to ensure that the essay flows smoothly from one section to another. Are there any sections of the essay that feel choppy or disconnected? If so, strive to make those sections more cohesive.

Lastly, let's look at the conclusion. It should serve as a summary of the process you have discussed and should reiterate the importance of the steps you have just outlined. Try to make sure that the conclusion leaves the reader with a sense of closure and understanding.

I learned about compound sentences with conjunctive adverbs.
‘Also, besides, furthermore, in addition, moreover’ are used to add a similar, equal idea. ‘However, nevertheless, nonetheless, still’ are used to add an unexpected or surprising continuation. ‘On the other hand, in contrast’ are used to add a complete contrast. ‘Otherwise’ is used to give an alternative possibility, often negative.
‘Accordingly, as a result, consequently, hence, therefore, thus’ are used to add an expected result.

Great, it sounds like you've got a good understanding of using compound sentences with conjunctive adverbs. Let's begin by reviewing your essay and identifying areas where you can incorporate these concepts.

First, let's focus on adding a similar or equal idea to your essay. Try using conjunctive adverbs like 'also', 'besides', 'furthermore', 'in addition', or 'moreover' to add more information to your sentences.

Next, let's use conjunctive adverbs to add an unexpected or surprising continuation. Use words like 'however', 'nevertheless', 'nonetheless', or 'still' to contrast ideas, or show an unexpected result.

To give a complete contrast, use 'on the other hand' or 'in contrast'.

If you want to give an alternative possibility (often negative), use 'otherwise'.

Lastly, use 'accordingly', 'as a result', 'consequently', 'hence', 'therefore', or 'thus' to add an expected result.

As you revise your essay, make sure you're using these conjunctive adverbs correctly, and that they fit naturally into the flow of your writing. Don't forget to read over your revised essay to make sure it is clear, concise, and easy to understand. Good luck!

For example, there are many elderly citizens who live alone in poverty and desperately need support. If the government's resources are spread too thin, these individuals are unlikely to get the assistance they require. Therefore, I believe that the government should concentrate its efforts on supporting the most disadvantaged members of society.

Secondly, it is unfair for wealthy individuals to receive government benefits when they don't need them. In order to create a more equitable society for everyone, I believe that the wealthy should pay higher taxes and be willing to contribute more to social welfare initiatives.

Overall, I believe that the government should focus its resources on aiding those who are most in need. This is particularly important given the deep divide between the rich and the poor in our society. I am confident that if we all work together and extend a helping hand to those who require it the most, we can create a better world for ourselves and for future generations. 

Great job! Your revised essay is clear and well-written, and your use of conjunctive adverbs has improved the flow of your writing. Keep up the good work!

  Firstly, if the government tries to help everyone, it is inevitable that some of the most vulnerable people in society will be overlooked. For example, there are many elderly citizens who live alone in poverty and desperately need support. If the government's resources are spread too thin, these individuals are unlikely to get the assistance they require. Therefore, I believe that the government should concentrate its efforts on supporting the most disadvantaged members of society.  
  Secondly, it is unfair for wealthy individuals to receive government benefits when they don't need them. I think that those who have an abundance of resources should be required to contribute more to society. For instance, it is a well-established fact that a small minority of individuals possess the majority of wealth in our country. In order to create a more equitable society for everyone, I believe that the wealthy should pay higher taxes and be willing to contribute more to social welfare initiatives.  
  Overall, I believe that the government should focus its resources on aiding those who are most in need. This is particularly important given the deep divide between the rich and the poor in our society. I am confident that if we all work together and extend a helping hand to those who require it the most, we can create a better world for ourselves and for future generations.

Great job! Your essay is well-structured and presents a clear argument. However, there are a few areas where you can improve. Let's go through each section of your essay and make the necessary revisions.

Introduction:
Your introduction is good, but it could be stronger. You should provide a bit more context and background information to help the reader understand the issue you are discussing. Additionally, your thesis statement could be more specific. Here's a revised introduction:

The issue of government assistance is a contentious one, with many people arguing that the government should help all citizens, while others believe that resources should be focused on those who are most in need. In this essay, I will argue that the government should prioritize helping the most vulnerable members of society. By doing so, we can create a more equitable society that benefits everyone.

Body:
Your body paragraphs are well-organized and present strong arguments. However, you could provide more evidence to support your claims. Additionally, you should address potential counterarguments to strengthen your position. Here are some revisions to your body paragraphs:

Paragraph 1:
Firstly, it is important to recognize that there are many vulnerable members of society who require government assistance. For example, elderly citizens who live alone in poverty often struggle to make ends meet and require support to maintain a decent standard of living. However, if the government tries to help everyone, it is inevitable that some of these individuals will be overlooked. This is because resources are limited, and it is difficult to provide comprehensive support to everyone. Therefore, it is essential that the government focuses its efforts on supporting the most disadvantaged members of society.

Paragraph 2:
Secondly, it is unfair for wealthy individuals to receive government benefits when they don't need them. While some argue that everyone should receive equal treatment, this ignores the fact that some people have more resources than others. In order to create a more equitable society, it is important that those who have an abundance of resources contribute more to social welfare initiatives. This can be achieved through higher taxes and other measures that ensure that the burden of supporting those in need is shared more equitably.

Conclusion:
Your conclusion is good, but it could be more impactful. You should restate your thesis statement and summarize your main arguments. Additionally, you could provide a call to action to encourage the reader to take action. Here's a revised conclusion:

In conclusion, the government should prioritize helping the most vulnerable members of society. By doing so, we can create a more equitable society that benefits everyone. This can be achieved through targeted support for those in need, as well as measures that ensure that the burden of supporting those in need is shared more equitably. I urge everyone to consider the importance of this issue and to take action to support those who require assistance. Together, we can create a better world for ourselves and for future generations.

Today we learned about the process essay. At the introduction it has hook which explain how the process relates to the reader's life and thesis statement which has purpose of informational or instructional. At the body paragraphs it guide the reader through the process. Each step is in sequential order. About the informational purpose of process essay, it uses third person pronouns. On the other hand, instructional purpose of process essay address the audience directly by using second person pronouns. It uses imperatives at the essay. Concluding papragraph summarizes the process and indicates its implications in a larger context.

Great, I see that you've learned a lot about the process essay. Let's work together to revise your essay based on these principles.

First, let's focus on your introduction. It's important to have a hook that grabs the reader's attention and relates the process to their life. Take a look at your hook and see if you can make it more engaging. Additionally, your thesis statement should clearly state the purpose of your process essay - whether it's informative or instructional.

Next, let's look at your body paragraphs. Make sure that they are organized in sequential order, guiding the reader through the process. Use transitions to clearly connect the steps together. For an instructional process essay, make sure you are addressing the audience directly with second person pronouns and imperatives. On the other hand, for an informative process essay, use third person pronouns.

Finally, wrap up your essay with a conclusion that summarizes the process and its implications. Think about how the process can be applied in a larger context or why it's important to know how to do this process.

Take your time revising your essay, and don't hesitate to ask for help if you need it. Good luck!
